{{< pagebreak >}}

```{r}
#| label: tbl-mod-est
#| tbl-cap: Estimates of global (non-hierarchical) parameters for base model (no covariates). Mean is the posterior mean, sd is the standard deviation of the parameter estimate, n_eff is effective number of MCMC draws, 2.5% and 97.5% cover the 95% credible interval of the parameter, 50% is the posterior median, and Rhat is a convergence diagnostic that compares variability within and among chains and should be close to one.
#| cache: true

to_summarize_ind <- sapply(mod@par_dims, \(x) length(x)==0) & 
  mod@model_pars != 'lp__'
to_summarize <- mod@model_pars[to_summarize_ind]
ordered_pars <- c(stringr::str_subset(to_summarize, '^(?!sigma)'), # does not start w/sigma
                  stringr::str_subset(to_summarize, 'sigma')) # contains sigma

mod_sum <- summary(mod, 
                   pars = ordered_pars, 
                   probs = c(0.025, 0.5, 0.975))
bind_cols(Variable = rownames(mod_sum$summary), mod_sum$summary) |>
  mutate(Variable = case_when(Variable == 'x0_mean' ~ '$\\mu_{L1}$',
                              Variable == 'sigma_x0' ~ '$\\sigma_{L1}$',
                              Variable == 'sigma_area' ~ '$\\sigma_r$',
                              Variable == 'U' ~ '$\\alpha_0$',
                              Variable == 'B' ~ '$\\alpha_1$',
                              Variable == 'U_season' ~ '$\\alpha_s$',
                              Variable == 'sigma_process' ~ '$\\sigma_p$',
                              Variable == 'sigma_obs' ~ '$\\sigma_o$')) |>
  select(-se_mean) |>
  knitr::kable(digits = 3)
```

{{< pagebreak >}}

```{r}
#| label: tbl-model-selection
#| tbl-cap: Expected log predictive density (ELPD) of candidate models and difference between each model and the model with the highest ELPD. Larger ELPDs indicate better predictive capacity.

loo_est |>
  loo::loo_compare() |> 
  data.frame() |>
  tibble::rownames_to_column(var = 'Model') |>
  mutate(Model = case_when(grepl('base', Model) ~ 'Base',
                           grepl('cuti_all_lat\\.', Model) ~ 'CUTI',
                           grepl('cuti_all_lat_sq', Model) ~ 'CUTI + CUTI$^2$',
                           grepl('beuti_all_lat\\.', Model) ~ 'BEUTI',
                           grepl('beuti_all_lat_sq', Model) ~ 'BEUTI + BEUTI$^2$',
                           grepl('Log_R', Model) ~ 'Log(R)')) |>
  select(Model, ELPD = elpd_loo, `$\\Delta$ELPD` = elpd_diff, `SE($\\Delta$ELPD)` = se_diff) |>
  knitr::kable(digits = 2)
```

# Figures

![Map of state statistical areas (courtesty of ODFW)](../figures/shrimp_areas.png){#fig-map width="4in"}

Maybe put map in supplement?

{{< pagebreak >}}

```{r}
#| label: fig-obs-data
#| fig-cap: "Length at age of shrimp by recruitment year and state area. State area number increases with latitude (i.e., area 32 borders Canada and area 12 is in California). See @fig-map for a map of state areas."
#| fig-height: 3.5
#| fig-width: 6.5

by_time <- lengths %>%
  group_by(Age_Month, Year_Class) %>%
  summarize(Avg_Len = mean(Avg_Len)) %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_line(aes(x=Age_Month-.33, y=Avg_Len, col = Year_Class, group = factor(Year_Class)),
            alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(x = 'Age', y = 'Average length (mm)', col = 'Recruitment\nyear') +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:3) +
  scale_color_gradientn(colours = rev(LaCroixColoR::lacroix_palette('Orange', 10))) +
  ylim(12, 25) 

library(beyonce)
by_space <- lengths %>%
  group_by(Age_Month, Area) %>%
  summarize(Avg_Len = mean(Avg_Len)) %>%
  ggplot() +
  geom_line(aes(x=Age_Month-.33, y=Avg_Len, col = Area, group = factor(Area)),
            alpha = 0.5) +
  labs(x = 'Age', y = 'Average length (mm)', col = 'State area') +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:3) +
  scale_color_manual(values = beyonce::beyonce_palette(number = 22, length(unique(lengths$Area)), type = 'continuous')) +
                       # PNWColors::pnw_palette('Sunset2', length(unique(lengths$Area)))) +
  ylim(12, 25) +
  guides(colour = guide_legend(override.aes = list(linewidth = 4)))

cowplot::plot_grid(by_time, by_space, nrow = 1, labels = 'auto', label_colour = theme_get()$axis.title$colour)
```

```{r}
#| label: fig-base
#| fig-cap: "Revenue per recruit as a function of fishing mortality rates for five different fishery opening dates and three different natural mortality rates. Dotted lines are at the low and high range of estimated fishing mortality in the fishery."
#| fig-height: 3.5
#| fig-width: 6.5

rpr_base_summary |>
  mutate(M.multiplier = recode(factor(M.multiplier), 
                               '1.25' = '25% increase in M',
                               '1' = 'Base M',
                               '0.75' = '25% decrease in M')) |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_line(aes(x = FF, y = mid, col = opening_fct, group = opening_fct)) +
  labs(x = 'F (1/mo)', y = 'Revenue per recruit', col = 'Opening date') +
  facet_wrap(~factor(M.multiplier)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = PNWColors::pnw_palette('Shuksan2', 5)) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0.03, col = theme_get()$axis.ticks$colour, lty = 'dotted') +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0.2, col = theme_get()$axis.ticks$colour, lty = 'dotted')
```

I have 2000 MCMC draws for each line so could provide measures of uncertainty (at least in growth) for this figure and those that follow. Is that worth it? It could get busy?

          which.min(abs(FF-0.1)),
          which.min(abs(FF-0.2)))) |>
  mutate(FF = paste('F =', round(FF, 2))) |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_point(aes(x = cohort, y = mid, col = opening_fct)) +
  scale_color_manual(values = PNWColors::pnw_palette('Shuksan2', 5)) +

I could make @fig-years like @fig-areas with one panel per year, or make @fig-areas like @fig-years, with only three panels. I thought 12 panels was fine so kept it that way, but 30 was too many so tried to find a way to summarize it.
